children.subject: Would you say taking 127 would be redundant for me?

Are you OP? Probably... a basic understanding of convexity gets you a decent way; I'd say the main benefit of 127 vs optimization in 189 is understanding duality. That, though, you could probably pick up as needed if you had to.
I took them in the opposite order, but wouldn't recommend 127 unless you plan on taking 227B+C later.

history.content:
I just finished taking EECS 127 and tbh it was one of the worst classes I've taken at Cal. I took it to "prepare" for CS 189 and while I can't tell you how the material in EECS 127 relates to CS 189 yet (I'm taking 189 next semester) I can tell you that this class is very poorly taught and organized and I learned about as much as I would have if I had self studied the material. Imo you're better off going over some in depth notes on convexity and optimization (the material on conic optimization in EECS 127 is super cursory, all you do is learn the basic frameworks of the models). I would suggest something like Stephen Boyd's textbook along with any other material you can find on convexity and duality (those were the main mathematically fleshed out topics). Other than that, there's nothing really new in EECS 127. The first 1/3 of the class is spent on linear algebra, half of which is review from math 54/EE 16A/EE 16B and half of which is new material that they go over in like 1-2 days with no sort of explanation or proofs or anything and expect you to know for the rest of the class. The last 1/4 is spent on "applications" where they vaguely try to relate the models you learned in the middle 1/3 to actual problems but the issue is that the models we're taught with barely any depth so any relation to "applications" is very cursory. Overall, would not recommend anyone take this class, you're better off taking math 110 or other classes that relate a little but to ML and EECS 127 and filling your (small) gap of knowledge in convex optimization from skipping this class by reading notes and doing problems on your own time.

________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Agree with above as I simply self studied the whole class. However, I think it is the best class you can take to prepare for a rigorous 189. To have a softer prep for 189, ds100 is recommended. If its your last semester at Cal, I would suggest taking another class instead.

children.subject: +1. I'm so sad I took it this sem instead of with her next sem. I think its great materials, it's just not actually taught to us.

+1. I took 127 in Spring 2018 after taking 189 in Fall 2018 with Sahai. Everything in 127 was too surface-level to actually learn anything. If you haven't taken 126 yet, I would recommend it over 127. However, I should add the disclaimer that I'm not sure how Ranade and Bayen will teach 127 next semester, since I didn't take it with them.

I also enjoyed Math 170 with Evans, since it introduced perspectives on optimization that were different from the 189-style heavy linear algebra perspective on optimization. Math 170 is definitely a lighter course than 126 or 127.

I agree with the student answer completely. I took the class last semester. The course needs some major rework... and a Professor who still cares to teach. I heard Prof. Ranade will be teaching 127 soon, and I think that’ll be awesome for the course.
off topic but thanks for being a great CS 70 TA Hermish!
Thanks for being a great person Hermish

+1 to Hermish being awesome :) also yeah I agree with his statements about the course, the content is very interesting and 127 is the beginning of a very rich theory that is developed very well in Boyd.

I think the material in the class was quite beautiful if you’re willing to put in a bit more work and go through some additional reference material (Boyd or El Ghaoui) for some more context/proofs. I really enjoyed the class overall!

history.content:
Anyone here take EECS127 after taking 189 with Sahai? Judging from this semesters's schedule (https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~elghaoui/Teaching/EECS127/Schedule_F18_v4.png), most of the course seems to be redundant with Sahai's iteration of 189. The only new material would be Conic Optimization and maybe some Applications. Can anyone comment on how much they got from the EECS127 after 189 with Sahai?

Next semester is my last semester at Berk, so I want to make it count.
history.subject: Taking EECS127 after taking CS189 with Sahai
